segment.source: Maintain Driver Configurations when Capturing a Windows Image
segment.target: Maintain Driver Configurations when Capturing a Windows Image

segment.source: Maintain Driver Configurations when Capturing a Windows Image
segment.target: Maintain Driver Configurations when Capturing a Windows Image

segment.source: Maintain Driver Configurations when Capturing a Windows Image
segment.target: Maintain Driver Configurations when Capturing a Windows Image

segment.source: A common deployment scenario is to capture a single Windows image from a reference computer and then apply the image to a group of destination computers that have identical hardware configurations.
segment.target: A common deployment scenario is to capture a single Windows image from a reference computer and then apply the image to a group of destination computers that have identical hardware configurations.

segment.source: To save time during installation and to speed up the out-of-box experience (OOBE) for end users, you can instruct Windows Setup to maintain the driver configurations from the reference computer as part of the Windows image.
segment.target: To save time during installation and to speed up the out-of-box experience (OOBE) for end users, you can instruct Windows Setup to maintain the driver configurations from the reference computer as part of the Windows image.

segment.source: You should do this only when the hardware on the reference computer and the hardware on the destination computers are identical.
segment.target: You should do this only when the hardware on the reference computer and the hardware on the destination computers are identical.

segment.source: When you do this, Windows Setup maintains driver configurations during image capture and deployment.
segment.target: When you do this, Windows Setup maintains driver configurations during image capture and deployment.

segment.source: In this topic:
segment.target: In this topic:

segment.source: Instructing Windows Setup to Maintain Driver Configurations
segment.target: Instructing Windows Setup to Maintain Driver Configurations

segment.source: Overview
segment.target: Overview

segment.source: Best Practices for Driver Revisions and Driver Ranking
segment.target: Best Practices for Driver Revisions and Driver Ranking

segment.target: Troubleshooting Hardware Configuration Differences

segment.source: Instructing Windows Setup to Maintain Driver Configurations
segment.target: Instructing Windows Setup to Maintain Driver Configurations

segment.source: Before you capture an image, generalize the computer by using an answer file that instructs Windows Setup to maintain the driver configurations.
segment.target: Before you capture an image, generalize the computer by using an answer file that instructs Windows Setup to maintain the driver configurations.

segment.source: To maintain driver configurations by using an answer file
segment.target: To maintain driver configurations by using an answer file

segment.source: On your technician computer, open Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).
segment.target: On your technician computer, open Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).

segment.source: Click Start, type Windows System Image Manager, and then select Windows System Image Manager.
segment.target: Click Start, type Windows System Image Manager, and then select Windows System Image Manager.

segment.source: Create a new answer file, or update an existing answer file.
segment.target: Create a new answer file, or update an existing answer file.

segment.source: For more information, see Create or Open an Answer File and Best Practices for Authoring Answer Files.
segment.target: For more information, see Create or Open an Answer File and Best Practices for Authoring Answer Files.

segment.source: Add the Microsoft-Windows-PnpSysprep/PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting.
segment.target: Add the Microsoft-Windows-PnpSysprep/PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting.

segment.source: For more information, see the Overview section in this topic.
segment.target: For more information, see the Overview section in this topic.

segment.source: If the computer has undetectable hardware, include the Microsoft-Windows-PnpSysprep/DoNotCleanUpNonPresentDevices setting.
segment.target: If the computer has undetectable hardware, include the Microsoft-Windows-PnpSysprep/DoNotCleanUpNonPresentDevices setting.

segment.source: For more information, see the Undetectable hardware section in this topic.
segment.target: For more information, see the Undetectable hardware section in this topic.

segment.source: Generalize the computer by using the answer file.
segment.target: Generalize the computer by using the answer file.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Overview
segment.target: Overview

segment.source: The Windows in-box driver packages include device drivers that support a wide variety of popular hardware.
segment.target: The Windows in-box driver packages include device drivers that support a wide variety of popular hardware.

segment.source: If your specific hardware requires additional device drivers to boot, you can preinstall additional device drivers on your Windows image.
segment.target: If your specific hardware requires additional device drivers to boot, you can preinstall additional device drivers on your Windows image.

segment.source: Independent Hardware Vendors (IHVs) often supply these additional device drivers together with their device hardware.
segment.target: Independent Hardware Vendors (IHVs) often supply these additional device drivers together with their device hardware.

segment.source: For more information about how to add device drivers, see Add a Driver Online in Audit Mode.
segment.target: For more information about how to add device drivers, see Add a Driver Online in Audit Mode.

segment.source: To prepare a Windows image for deployment to multiple computers, you must use the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool to generalize the Windows image.
segment.target: To prepare a Windows image for deployment to multiple computers, you must use the System Preparation (Sysprep) tool to generalize the Windows image.

segment.source: Generalizing a Windows image removes the computer-specific information and prepares the device drivers for first boot.
segment.target: Generalizing a Windows image removes the computer-specific information and prepares the device drivers for first boot.

segment.source: This preparation includes these steps:
segment.target: This preparation includes these steps:

segment.source: Device state for hardware is removed.
segment.target: Device state for hardware is removed.

segment.source: Boot-critical driver settings are reset to their default values.
segment.target: Boot-critical driver settings are reset to their default values.

segment.source: Device log files are deleted.
segment.target: Device log files are deleted.

segment.source: When you generalize the computer, use an answer file that has the Microsoft-Windows-PnpSysPrepPersistAllDeviceInstalls setting to save time.
segment.target: When you generalize the computer, use an answer file that has the Microsoft-Windows-PnpSysPrepPersistAllDeviceInstalls setting to save time.

segment.source: This setting prevents Windows Setup from removing and reconfiguring the device state for identical hardware.
segment.target: This setting prevents Windows Setup from removing and reconfiguring the device state for identical hardware.

segment.source: On first boot, the detected device drivers are already preconfigured, potentially enabling a quicker first-boot experience.
segment.target: On first boot, the detected device drivers are already preconfigured, potentially enabling a quicker first-boot experience.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Avoid using the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting when the hardware and the hardware configuration on the reference computer are not identical to those of the destination computers.
segment.target: Avoid using the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting when the hardware and the hardware configuration on the reference computer are not identical to those of the destination computers.

segment.source: Even seemingly minor differences in hardware or hardware configuration can cause severe or easily overlooked problems.
segment.target: Even seemingly minor differences in hardware or hardware configuration can cause severe or easily overlooked problems.

segment.source: For more information, see the Troubleshooting Hardware Configuration Differences section of this topic.
segment.target: For more information, see the Troubleshooting Hardware Configuration Differences section of this topic.

segment.source: It's a good practice not to use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting on your primary reference image.
segment.target: It's a good practice not to use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting on your primary reference image.

segment.source: Instead, for each group of computers that have a different hardware configuration, first load your primary reference image onto a new reference computer that has the planned hardware configuration.
segment.target: Instead, for each group of computers that have a different hardware configuration, first load your primary reference image onto a new reference computer that has the planned hardware configuration.

segment.source: Next, capture a new image of this setup and use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting.
segment.target: Next, capture a new image of this setup and use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting.

segment.source: For more information about how to generalize the Windows image, see Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation.
segment.target: For more information about how to generalize the Windows image, see Sysprep (Generalize) a Windows installation.

segment.source: Best Practices for Driver Revisions and Driver Ranking
segment.target: Best Practices for Driver Revisions and Driver Ranking

segment.source: Don't maintain multiple versions or revisions of the same driver package in the same image.
segment.target: Don't maintain multiple versions or revisions of the same driver package in the same image.

segment.source: Use offline or online servicing tools to update drivers.
segment.target: Use offline or online servicing tools to update drivers.

segment.source: Normally, when Windows Setup boots a computer and multiple versions of a driver package exist on that computer, Setup determines which driver to install by using driver ranking.
segment.target: Normally, when Windows Setup boots a computer and multiple versions of a driver package exist on that computer, Setup determines which driver to install by using driver ranking.

segment.source: But when you use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting, the normal driver-ranking processes don't occur.
segment.target: But when you use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting, the normal driver-ranking processes don't occur.

segment.source: So, devices that use outdated drivers may remain installed.
segment.target: So, devices that use outdated drivers may remain installed.

segment.source: For more information about driver ranking, see How Windows Ranks Drivers on MSDN.
segment.target: For more information about driver ranking, see How Windows Ranks Drivers on MSDN.

segment.source: If you must add a device driver to an image that uses the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting, you can update your device drivers by using one of the following methods:
segment.target: If you must add a device driver to an image that uses the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting, you can update your device drivers by using one of the following methods:

segment.source: Use offline servicing tools, like the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool or an unattended answer file.
segment.target: Use offline servicing tools, like the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool or an unattended answer file.

segment.source: For more information, see Add and Remove Drivers to an Offline Windows Image.
segment.target: For more information, see Add and Remove Drivers to an Offline Windows Image.

segment.source: Use online servicing methods or tools, like an unattended answer file.
segment.target: Use online servicing methods or tools, like an unattended answer file.

segment.source: For more information, see Add a Driver Online in Audit Mode.
segment.target: For more information, see Add a Driver Online in Audit Mode.

segment.source: Troubleshooting Hardware Configuration Differences
segment.target: Troubleshooting Hardware Configuration Differences

segment.source: For the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting to work correctly, the hardware configuration must be identical on the reference computer and on the destination computers.
segment.target: For the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting to work correctly, the hardware configuration must be identical on the reference computer and on the destination computers.

segment.source: Hardware configuration includes the following components:
segment.target: Hardware configuration includes the following components:

segment.source: Hardware make and model.
segment.target: Hardware make and model.

segment.source: Firmware.
segment.target: Firmware.

segment.source: Updates, revisions, and configuration differences can cause some devices to report different criteria for matching device drivers or to use different resources.
segment.target: Updates, revisions, and configuration differences can cause some devices to report different criteria for matching device drivers or to use different resources.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Peripheral Component Interconnect (PCI)–based devices can embed different subsystem revision numbers in their reported hardware IDs.
segment.target: Peripheral Component Interconnect (PCI)–based devices can embed different subsystem revision numbers in their reported hardware IDs.

segment.source: BIOS revisions can change the Advanced Configuration and Power Interface (ACPI) namespace.
segment.target: BIOS revisions can change the Advanced Configuration and Power Interface (ACPI) namespace.

segment.source: This causes Windows Setup to report existing devices differently or to introduce existing devices as new devices.
segment.target: This causes Windows Setup to report existing devices differently or to introduce existing devices as new devices.

segment.source: BIOS system configuration differences can cause system devices to claim different memory, I/O, direct memory access (DMA), or interrupt request (IRQ) resources.
segment.target: BIOS system configuration differences can cause system devices to claim different memory, I/O, direct memory access (DMA), or interrupt request (IRQ) resources.

segment.source: Physical location.
segment.target: Physical location.

segment.source: Hardware configurations must use the same slot, port, or socket numbers to connect to external devices.
segment.target: Hardware configurations must use the same slot, port, or socket numbers to connect to external devices.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: PCI expansion cards must be inserted in the same slot numbers.
segment.target: PCI expansion cards must be inserted in the same slot numbers.

segment.source: USB devices must be connected or wired to the same port numbers on the same USB host controllers and integrated hubs.
segment.target: USB devices must be connected or wired to the same port numbers on the same USB host controllers and integrated hubs.

segment.source: Storage devices must be connected to the same storage controllers and channels.
segment.target: Storage devices must be connected to the same storage controllers and channels.

segment.source: Low-risk, medium-risk, and high-risk differences in hardware configuration
segment.target: Low-risk, medium-risk, and high-risk differences in hardware configuration

segment.source: When you use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting, any hardware differences can potentially cause problems.
segment.target: When you use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting, any hardware differences can potentially cause problems.

segment.source: But some differences are more likely to cause problems than others.
segment.target: But some differences are more likely to cause problems than others.

segment.source: Low-risk differences
segment.target: Low-risk differences

segment.source: For the following types of hardware differences, you may be able to work around potential driver conflicts and still use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting:
segment.target: For the following types of hardware differences, you may be able to work around potential driver conflicts and still use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting:

segment.source: CPU clock speed
segment.target: CPU clock speed

segment.source: Amount of memory
segment.target: Amount of memory

segment.source: Hard disk capacity
segment.target: Hard disk capacity

segment.source: External input devices, like keyboards and mouse devices
segment.target: External input devices, like keyboards and mouse devices

segment.source: Monitors
segment.target: Monitors

segment.source: Medium-risk differences
segment.target: Medium-risk differences

segment.source: For the following types of hardware differences, we recommend that you don't use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting:
segment.target: For the following types of hardware differences, we recommend that you don't use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting:

segment.source: Video cards
segment.target: Video cards

segment.source: Storage drives and media readers, like optical drives and card readers
segment.target: Storage drives and media readers, like optical drives and card readers

segment.source: Internal or integrated bus devices, like USB or 1394 devices
segment.target: Internal or integrated bus devices, like USB or 1394 devices

segment.source: When these types of hardware differences exist, using this setting may not reduce installation time, even if you work around potential driver conflicts.
segment.target: When these types of hardware differences exist, using this setting may not reduce installation time, even if you work around potential driver conflicts.

segment.source: High-risk differences
segment.target: High-risk differences

segment.source: For major hardware differences, don't use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting.
segment.target: For major hardware differences, don't use the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting.

segment.source: These differences include:
segment.target: These differences include:

segment.source: Motherboard chipset or CPU brand
segment.target: Motherboard chipset or CPU brand

segment.source: Storage controllers
segment.target: Storage controllers

segment.source: Form-factor differences, like a change from a desktop to a laptop or from a laptop to a desktop
segment.target: Form-factor differences, like a change from a desktop to a laptop or from a laptop to a desktop

segment.source: Keyboard layout differences, like a change from a standard 101-key keyboard to a Japanese 106-key keyboard
segment.target: Keyboard layout differences, like a change from a standard 101-key keyboard to a Japanese 106-key keyboard

segment.source: Any other devices that are in the enumeration path of the Windows boot volume
segment.target: Any other devices that are in the enumeration path of the Windows boot volume

segment.source: Types of problems that can occur with a hardware configuration change
segment.target: Types of problems that can occur with a hardware configuration change

segment.source: Even seemingly minor differences in hardware or hardware configuration can cause severe or easily overlooked problems, like these:
segment.target: Even seemingly minor differences in hardware or hardware configuration can cause severe or easily overlooked problems, like these:

segment.source: System instability
segment.target: System instability

segment.source: Inability to use some of the basic or extended functionality of a device
segment.target: Inability to use some of the basic or extended functionality of a device

segment.source: Extended boot times and extended installation times
segment.target: Extended boot times and extended installation times

segment.source: Misnamed devices in the Devices and Printers folder, Device Manager, and other device-related user interfaces
segment.target: Misnamed devices in the Devices and Printers folder, Device Manager, and other device-related user interfaces

segment.source: Severe system problems that leave the computer in a non-bootable state
segment.target: Severe system problems that leave the computer in a non-bootable state

segment.source: Hardware configuration differences that can cause system boot failures
segment.target: Hardware configuration differences that can cause system boot failures

segment.source: When the boot-critical hardware is not identical on the reference computer and destination computers, using the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting can cause severe system problems that can leave the computer in a non-bootable state.
segment.target: When the boot-critical hardware is not identical on the reference computer and destination computers, using the PersistAllDeviceInstalls setting can cause severe system problems that can leave the computer in a non-bootable state.

segment.source: Boot-critical driver packages can belong to any of the following Windows device setup classes, as identified by the ClassGUID directive in the Version section of the .inf files in their driver packages.
segment.target: Boot-critical driver packages can belong to any of the following Windows device setup classes, as identified by the ClassGUID directive in the Version section of the .inf files in their driver packages.

segment.source: System-supplied device setup class
segment.target: System-supplied device setup class

segment.source: ClassGUID
segment.target: ClassGUID

segment.source: System
segment.target: System

segment.source: Computer
segment.target: Computer

segment.source: Processor
segment.target: Processor

segment.source: PCMCIA
segment.target: PCMCIA

segment.source: HDC
segment.target: HDC

segment.source: SCSIAdapter
segment.target: SCSIAdapter

segment.source: DiskDrive
segment.target: DiskDrive

segment.source: CDROM
segment.target: CDROM

segment.source: FDC
segment.target: FDC

segment.source: FloppyDisk
segment.target: FloppyDisk

segment.source: Volume
segment.target: Volume

segment.source: USB
segment.target: USB

segment.source: SBP2
segment.target: SBP2

segment.source: Enum1394
segment.target: Enum1394

segment.source: Keyboard
segment.target: Keyboard

segment.source: Mouse
segment.target: Mouse

segment.source: HIDClass
segment.target: HIDClass

segment.source: Ports
segment.target: Ports

segment.source: For more information about these device setup classes, see System-Supplied Device Setup Classes on MSDN.
segment.target: For more information about these device setup classes, see System-Supplied Device Setup Classes on MSDN.

segment.source: Undetectable hardware
segment.target: Undetectable hardware

segment.source: When you deploy a new computer to an end user, some hardware, like a removable device or a device that has an on/off switch, may not be present or detected during first boot.
segment.target: When you deploy a new computer to an end user, some hardware, like a removable device or a device that has an on/off switch, may not be present or detected during first boot.

segment.source: By default, on first boot, Windows Setup removes the preconfigured device state for undetected hardware.
segment.target: By default, on first boot, Windows Setup removes the preconfigured device state for undetected hardware.

segment.source: To deploy hardware that may not be present or detected on first boot, add any applicable device drivers to the reference image, connect or turn on the applicable devices so that Windows can install them, and use the Microsoft-Windows-PnpSysprep/DoNotCleanUpNonPresentDevices setting when you capture the image.
segment.target: To deploy hardware that may not be present or detected on first boot, add any applicable device drivers to the reference image, connect or turn on the applicable devices so that Windows can install them, and use the Microsoft-Windows-PnpSysprep/DoNotCleanUpNonPresentDevices setting when you capture the image.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Using the DoNotCleanUpNonPresentDevices setting can lead to the unnecessary storage of excess device states and contribute to slower boot times.
segment.target: Using the DoNotCleanUpNonPresentDevices setting can lead to the unnecessary storage of excess device states and contribute to slower boot times.

segment.source: Troubleshooting Driver Conflicts
segment.target: Troubleshooting Driver Conflicts

segment.source: To avoid driver conflicts between independent boot-critical driver packages, the IHV must make sure that each device driver uses different service names, registry key values, and binary file names.
segment.target: To avoid driver conflicts between independent boot-critical driver packages, the IHV must make sure that each device driver uses different service names, registry key values, and binary file names.

segment.source: Example of a potential driver conflict
segment.target: Example of a potential driver conflict

segment.source: In the following example, a fictitious IHV named Fabrikam produces two types of storage controllers: StandardController and ExtremeController.
segment.target: In the following example, a fictitious IHV named Fabrikam produces two types of storage controllers: StandardController and ExtremeController.

segment.source: Fabrikam assumes that only one type of storage controller is installed at a time on a particular computer.
segment.target: Fabrikam assumes that only one type of storage controller is installed at a time on a particular computer.

segment.source: The driver package defines the StandardController and ExtremeController configurations to use the same driver service name, storctrl.
segment.target: The driver package defines the StandardController and ExtremeController configurations to use the same driver service name, storctrl.

segment.source: The storctrl driver service uses different service settings that change depending on which hardware (StandardController or ExtremeController) is installed.
segment.target: The storctrl driver service uses different service settings that change depending on which hardware (StandardController or ExtremeController) is installed.

segment.source: Because both StandardController and ExtremeController use the same service, they cannot coexist.
segment.target: Because both StandardController and ExtremeController use the same service, they cannot coexist.

segment.source: This sample shows the contents of the driver package file Storctrl.inf:
segment.target: This sample shows the contents of the driver package file Storctrl.inf:

segment.source: If StandardController is on the reference computer and its settings are maintained during image capture, the storctrl driver service is preconfigured.
segment.target: If StandardController is on the reference computer and its settings are maintained during image capture, the storctrl driver service is preconfigured.

segment.source: If ExtremeController is on the destination computer, Windows may use the preconfigured settings and files that are intended for StandardController.
segment.target: If ExtremeController is on the destination computer, Windows may use the preconfigured settings and files that are intended for StandardController.

segment.source: This can cause unexpected results.
segment.target: This can cause unexpected results.

segment.source: The IHV can help resolve the conflict by using one of these options:
segment.target: The IHV can help resolve the conflict by using one of these options:

segment.source: Create separate driver packages that have separate .inf files for each configuration, and import only the required driver package into the Windows image during deployment.
segment.target: Create separate driver packages that have separate .inf files for each configuration, and import only the required driver package into the Windows image during deployment.

segment.source: For example, split Storctrl.inf into two separate .inf files, one version for StandardController and one version for ExtremeController, and import only the required driver package into the Windows image.
segment.target: For example, split Storctrl.inf into two separate .inf files, one version for StandardController and one version for ExtremeController, and import only the required driver package into the Windows image.

segment.source: Create another service in the driver package for each configuration.
segment.target: Create another service in the driver package for each configuration.

segment.source: Give each service a different name (for example, storctrl and storctrlx) and point to a different binary image file (for example, Storctrl.sys and Storctrlx.sys).
segment.target: Give each service a different name (for example, storctrl and storctrlx) and point to a different binary image file (for example, Storctrl.sys and Storctrlx.sys).

segment.target: Related topics
